attributes.action: Stop water pollution in the Lake District
attributes.background: I want there should be a ban on water pollution in the Lake District world heritage site. I was disgusted to find out that raw sewage was allowed to flow into Lake Windermere for 1700 hours in 2020 as part of the overflow system at Ambleside waste management plant.
attributes.additional_details: I believe this issue requires governmental intervention to make it law and to hold those who do pollute the lakes, rivers and waters to be held accountable. I want the rivers and lakes to be clean for the people that utilise them and especially for the wildlife that call the Lake District home.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or House of Commons is responsible for.

Decisions about managing pollution in the Lake District are a matter for the relevant local authorities and environmental agencies, not the Government or House of Commons. As a result it is not possible for the Government or House of Commons to take the action you have requested.

We have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Ban Water Companies discharging raw sewage into water courses: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/582336

attributes.action: I would like you to stop exporting plastic waste from the UK to poorer countries
attributes.background: The UK currently is the second largest exporter of plastic to poorer countries. The EU have banned export of plastic from 1 January 2021, however we have not. The plastic that we export often ends up in the ocean polluting the ecosystems of our planet, or it is burnt or ends up as land fill waste.
attributes.additional_details: We need to be leading the way on environmental issues such as this. It is not okay for the UK to be exporting plastic. We should be actively looking into sustainable alternatives to plastic use in the UK and also stepping up our own recycling abilities. It is also not okay that we are asking poorer countries to take our waste, for then it to pollute the environment in so many harmful ways. This is a global concern, that we have the utmost responsibility for.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/331061

attributes.action: Keep Main Roads Open Permanently
attributes.background: Don’t allow funding to Authorities that close roads permanently without a really good reason, this causes more congestion as more forced down one road instead of various which eases traffic, this will damage the economy locally if people find it differ to go in to town centres and city centres.
attributes.additional_details: Prevent unnecessary Permanent Road closures across the the U.K. and help keep the economy alive, also traffic flowing more freely prevents higher pollution and stop narrow minded authorities doing a quick cash grab on the Covid money been given by closing Roads. If we’re caring for environmental protection we keep roads open to make the traffic move on more quickly than be bottle necked queueing, look at towns with bad road management and their economic problems, the cycle incentives never work

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. If you are concerned about specific road closures you could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors
                
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do. For example, we could accept a petition calling for the Government to suspend funding for improving cycle lanes if they reduce car capacity, if that is something you would like to see happen.

attributes.action: Do not use 27-acre site in Ashford for lorry park or border control post
attributes.background:
The Government should not use the 27-acre site of beautiful Kentish countryside for a post-Brexit customs centre or lorry park.
 
HGV vehicles are highly polluting, and increasing HGV traffic to this area could have a substantial effect on local air pollution.
attributes.additional_details: Not only is the Brexit lorry park bad for local biodiversity and air quality, but it also threatens disruption to traffic to and from the local William Harvey Hospital and has angered many local residents feeling disregarded.

attributes.action: Close the Royal Parks to vehicle traffic
attributes.background:
Since government restrictions the parks have been a new haven for all to enjoy exercise safely and pollution free.

In particular Bushey Park. Wheelchair users and those in mobility vehicles have been out in largenumbers.
attributes.additional_details: Debate the need for cars to be in these areas. We have valuable wildlife and deer roaming. With pollution a focus point, there needs to be freedom from the car in these places.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Make balloon release illegal
attributes.background: I would like to ban the release of balloons into the sky and the environment as it only ever comes to harm to our animals and eco system.
attributes.additional_details: Ingesting balloons can cause death by blocking the digestive and/or respiratory tracts. This has been witnessed and documented in marine and farm animals. Balloons don't decompose quickly, and their strings usually aren't made of biodegradable material, either. All released balloons, including those falsely marketed as “biodegradable latex,” return to Earth. They kill animals and cause power outages. Balloons can travel miles and pollute remote and pristine places.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign this petition calling for the same thing: 

Make releasing helium balloons and sky lanterns a specific littering offence
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/609032

attributes.action: Department of Transport to commission study into solving Dartford traffic
attributes.background: We believe the scale of traffic issues & the negative impact it has on Dartford is too big to be solved with small measures. We call upon the Department for Transport to fully investigate the causes of our gridlock and then take the actions  needed to deliver long term solutions.
attributes.additional_details:
Dartford suffers from serious traffic gridlock that brings roads to a standstill. This is more than simply an inconvenience: it has a crippling effect on people's lives and the gridlock is damaging our local economy with residents unable to access local businesses. 

It is also a public health emergency. Stationary traffic causes air pollution & Dartford has the 2nd highest average daily level of air pollution of all local authorities in the southeast of England

rejection.details:
We understand you're concerned about traffic in Dartford, however we're not sure whether you are concerned about traffic in or around the town of Dartford itself, or traffic using the Dartford Crossing. 

In any case, decisions relating to traffic in Dartford town or the wider area would be a planning matter for Kent County Council, not the UK Government or Parliament. You could start a petition on the Kent Council website asking them to take such action, if that is something you'd like to see happen. You can find out how to do this here: https://democracy.kent.gov.uk/mgepetitionlistdisplay.aspx?bcr=1.

You may also like to sign this petition which calls for a related action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/587984

attributes.action: Raise littering fines to encourage people to use the bins provided.
attributes.background: Raise the current littering fines to a substantial sum. This will make people think twice before throwing litter from car windows or not using the provided bins when out walking.
attributes.additional_details: To help the natural environment, help protect wildlife from pollution and to make the towns and countryside a more healthy and beeter place to be.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334297

attributes.action: Start a discussion to ban the public sale of fireworks.
attributes.background:
Start a discussion to ban the public sale of fireworks and prohibit displays to lisenced events.

Unlisenced public use of fireworks is dangerous, a public inconvenience, polluting and antisocial.

They harm animals both wild and domestic.
attributes.additional_details:
I would be greatful for the government to discuss tougher controls on the public sale of fireworks and the consequences for the miss use of such explosives.

Fireworks are becoming antisocial and dangerous.  The constant banging at this time of year is detrimental to peoples mental health and to the well-being of pets, domestic animals and wildlife.

Restricting the sale of such explosives to lisenced professionals who conduct appropriate risk assessments before an event is essential to safety

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319891

attributes.action: Limit the Impact of Climate Change with air mileage allowance
attributes.background: An air mile allowance would help to limit or reduce the effects of the climate crisis by preventing excess air travel. An annual air mileage allowance for one adult could be equivalent to 1x long haul and 1x short haul flight a year. Any unused allowance could be sold/bought on an official exchange.
attributes.additional_details:
A return flight from London to San Francisco emits more than twice the emissions produced by a family car in a year (BBC, 2020). 

As the world returns to normal following the COVID-19 pandemic, the number of flights are set to increase, especially with the effects of ‘revenge pollution’.
Without an air mile allowance, the government could impose air travel restrictions by increasing the cost of plane tickets. An air mile allowance ensures fair travel opportunities for all.

attributes.action: Prioritise the development of a sustainable circular economy.
attributes.background: Up to 99% of goods end up in landfills or are burned to produce fuel (EfW) within 6 months of purchase. This is both inherently wasteful and bad for the planet. An SCE makes better use of resources than our current linear economy, prevents waste and pollution, and provides employment in recycling.
attributes.additional_details: For the sake of current and future generations, we have to be more responsible in our use of resources. Energy from Waste (EfW) has only minor benefits - producing fuel - as against major deficits - waste of resources and increased pollution. A linear economy uses increasing amounts of virgin resources which is unsustainable. Recycling is still underutilized. An ESC would be a sustainable economy going forward into the future. This is based on research from the University of Leeds.

rejection.details:
We understand that you want the Government to make the UK more sustainable, but it's not clear what action you want the Government to take to achieve this. We can only accept petitions that request a clear action.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Rebuild the economy out of lockdown with a Green New Deal: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/317343

Publish new carbon budgets linked to the Paris Agreement and Climate Change Act: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/300178

Make recycling a legal obligation: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/331864

attributes.action: De-Trafficafy Norwood Road
attributes.background: To influence the closure of Norwood Road to traffic or to introduce a congestion charge in order to reduce the noise pollution.
attributes.additional_details: Norwood Road is becoming way too busy and the noise from the traffic is outrageous. We need to get a debate going in parliament to look at the possibility of closing it off to buses and cars etc in order to restore peace and quiet to the neighbourhood.

rejection.details:
Decisions about local traffic management are a matter for individual local authorities, not the Government or House of Commons.

You could raise this issue with a local councillor, who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them: https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

You can also petition your local council directly. Find out how to petition your council here: https://moderngov.lambeth.gov.uk/mgePetitionListDisplay.aspx

attributes.action: Give us back our roads - Stop LTNs Now!
attributes.background: London's roads are gridlocked so a few privileged residents can enjoy car free streets.  There are over 300 parks and ‘public open spaces’, in London. Together they cover almost 18% of London which is more than the area of the city covered by railways and roads combined.
attributes.additional_details: This scheme is not designed at cutting pollution - it is a blatant war on motorists.  It is not tackling pollution it is moving it to the less gentrified neighbourhoods.  Pollution could be drastically reduced by taxing vehicles with highest emissions essential car/van users need to keep moving to keep London's economy going.  These LTNs are adding 50% in car time, stopping and starting.  Don't let a few elitists dictate how London operates.

rejection.details:
Decisions about low traffic neighbourhoods in London are a matter for individual London boroughs, not the UK Government or House of Commons. Decisions about the low emission zone and any associated charges are a matter for TfL and the London Assembly.

We have published a related petition which you might like to sign:

Impose stricter requirements on reallocation of road space by local authorities: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/550887

attributes.action: Stop bonfires in residential areas before 10.30pm
attributes.background: Bonfires within residential areas are becoming more of an issue. The local authority advise against them but have no powers to stop them if they are controlled.
attributes.additional_details: This has been an issue for many years within local communities. However since the covid19 pandemic local councils have been unable to collect garden waste and household waste recycling centres have not been open as often. This is only causing an issue for local residents and polluting the environment.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310468

attributes.action: Ban the use of sky lanterns.
attributes.background:
We would like the sale and use of sky (Chinese) lanterns banned in the United Kingdom. These small lanterns use naked flames to enable the lantern to float into the sky. They cannot be controlled and as a result can fall anywhere.

We would like it to be against the law to sell or use these.
attributes.additional_details:
Sky lanterns are dangerous as the cannot be controlled, they can fall anywhere and have been responsible for starting numerous fires. They have also landed on livestock causing serious injuries to animals, meaning some have had to be euthanised. 

The remains often contain wires which in themselves can cause injuries to wildlife, as well as causing pollution.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310556

attributes.action: Seek to rejoin the European Environment Agency
attributes.background: We want the Government to seek to rejoin the European Environment Agency (EEA), so that up to date UK environmental information is published alongside that of EU nations, in a clear, transparent and responsible way.
attributes.additional_details:
EEA environmental data no longer covers the UK, and we believe this has resulted in a reduction in the accessibility of transparent environmental information relating to the UK.
 
We believe the UK's membership of the EEA would mean better access to up to date UK environmental information, which is needed so the public can see how bad the climate and environmental situation is regarding pollution and the spread of various organisms throughout Europe, for example anopheles mosquitoes.

attributes.action: Introduce A Scheme Where People Are Paid At Least £5 for Every Tree They Plant
attributes.background: The climate crisis is imminently serious and the Government and people in general are not taking it seriously enough. The rainforests are being destroyed. The ice is melting. Animals are going extinct. People’s health is failing and people are actually dying because of this crisis.
attributes.additional_details:
Trees are an amazing asset to help tackle the climate crisis and ensure the continued existence of life on Earth. They take in carbon dioxide and produce oxygen that we all need to breathe. They reduce pollution. They also provide homes and food for animals.
 A financial incentive for everyone to plant more trees could greatly benefit native wildlife and the air we all need!
 Just think of how many more trees would be planted if people were paid at least £5 for every tree they planted!

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Stop Farnborough Civic Quarter development plans to cut 237 trees!
attributes.background:
We the constituents of Rushmoor District object to the unnecessary destruction of 237 mature trees which would take place if RBC's current plan for the development of Farnborough Civic Quarter goes ahead. 
This action conflicts with RBC's own Local Plan and adversely impacts the community:
attributes.additional_details:
The trees provide shade combating the urban heat-island effect.

They absorb C02 and felling them means the loss of carbon sinks combating climate change. 

Decrease in air quality close to the airport.

People living in the town centre will be affected by noise pollution.

A lack of green spaces has a negative effect on people's mental health. 

It will cause a huge loss of biodiversity and habitat for wildlife.

We are challenging this development on the grounds of RBC's own Local Plan.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about local developments are a matter for the relevant local authority, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them, by entering your post code here:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

Rushmoor Borough Council also has its own petitions scheme, which you can find out about here: https://www.rushmoor.gov.uk/media/h5ioha4n/12_-_new_petitions_scheme.pdf

attributes.action: Stop the rollout of National 20 mph speed limit on B roads in Wales
attributes.background: Keep the limit at 30 mph,except where it is now 20 mph,I.e.outside of schools etc.
attributes.additional_details: It’s impractical and leads to more fuel usage and pollution.

rejection.details:
Your petition is about something that the Welsh Government is responsible for. That means that the UK Government and Parliament can't look into it.

The Welsh Parliament has its own Petitions Committee.

If you'd like to send your petition to the Welsh Parliament, you can find out more here: https://petitions.senedd.wales/

attributes.action: Remove the 'temporary' traffic lights at the Parkway Station rail bridge
attributes.background: Please remove these lights and temporary road narrowing as soon as possible as they are stopping residents accessing their own homes and are increasing local pollution levels.
attributes.additional_details:
The traffic coming into Stoke Gifford has become unbearable and made it impossible to access the Ratcliffe Drive / Sandringham Road /North Road areas as traffic is backed up to Aviva in one direction and Winterbourne Road in the other. The problem is further worsened by the ongoing road closure at Gipsy Patch Lane railway bridge.
Although the lights were provided to widen the pedestrian/cyclist access, the fact that the space is part road and part pavement makes it difficult to use as a cyclist and the current pollution levels must surely be offsetting any benefit.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or House of Commons is responsible for. Decisions about local traffic restrictions are a matter for your local authority, not the Government or House of Commons. As a result it is not possible for the Government or House of Commons to take the action you have requested.

You could raise this issue with a local councillor, who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them: https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Stop councils from making roads with illegally high pollution even worse
attributes.background: Amend the Road Traffic Regulation Act 1984 to require any traffic authority making a traffic order to monitor air quality before and during a scheme, on any roads likely to be impacted by changes, and to suspend the scheme if levels above established safe standards (eg 40 ug/m3 NO2 annual mean).
attributes.additional_details: Local councils and TFL currently have the ability to divert or displace traffic for up to 18 months without consultation, potentially benefiting residents of one road to the detriment of others. Residents of roads suffering from displaced traffic cannot claim compensation. It is vital to protect these residents - more likely to be in poverty or BAME, and less likely to own a car - from the harmful effects of such schemes. The precautionary principle should apply to traffic orders.

rejection.details:
Local authorities already have legal responsibilities to tackle emissions where these exceed national objectives. This includes using traffic and parking management. You can read more about Local Government air quality responsibilities here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-8804/

We have published the following related petitions, which you might like to sign:

Remove guidance and funding for temporary traffic measures that cause congestion: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552306

Impose stricter requirements on reallocation of road space by local authorities: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/550887

attributes.action: Make ALL water pollution into ANY body of natrual water a major crime.
attributes.background: All forms of pollution into any natural body of water to be completely OUTLAWED.
attributes.additional_details:
Agricultural and farming waste, industrial waste,  sewage and water company waste,  Livestock waste,  septic tank waste, oil waste.   

No types of waste or byproducts at all should be allowed into waterways, rivers and seas. 

No ifs, no buts, no maybes. 

All enterprises has to be responsible for there own waste. Waterways are a dumping ground.  

We are on the verge of ecological breakdown and unless this stops with we see a human and environmental health crisis of epic proportions.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action. We understand that you're concerned about water pollution, but we're not sure exactly what you want the Government or Parliament to do.

There are already offences for:

- discharging poisonous, noxious or polluting matter or solid waste matter into inland freshwater, coastal waters and relevant territorial waters.

- discharging trade or sewage effluent into inland freshwater, coastal waters and relevant territorial waters.

It's unclear what additional actions you want to be made an offence, or if and how you want penalties for existing offences to be changed.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Provide global climate leadership by ending any new UK oil and gas extraction
attributes.background: Greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel burning are choking our planet and putting billions of people at immediate risk. But the UK Government plans to allow new oil and gas fields to start up between now and 2050. The UK Government must change policy and stop any new UK oil and gas extraction.
attributes.additional_details:
The viability of our societies depends on limiting global temperature rise to 1.5°C above the pre-industrial era average. It has already risen 1.1°C. 

Without deep carbon and methane pollution cuts (from burning fossil fuels) between now and 2030, the 1.5°C goal is unachievable. 

The UK Government must show global climate leadership by ending any new oil and gas extraction and announce support for a rapid expansion of renewable energy and a plan for increasing energy efficiency of UK homes.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/594797

attributes.action: Reopen the recently pedestrianised parts of St Albans City Centre
attributes.background:
We the undersigned petition the County Council to undertake the necessary studies and public consultation to re-open city centre pedestrianisation of St Albans (to include George Street and Market Place).
The recent COVID-19 closures have led to vastly increased air pollution and traffic congestion
attributes.additional_details:
Eradicate damage to historical buildings by imposing weight/size restrictions on George Street and Market Place. Reopen current closed roads to cars, decreasing the congestion & pollution the road closures have caused.
Closures negatively impact surrounding residents who have not been consulted at any point to date. 
Pedestrian safety has never been an issue on these roads but emergency vehicles are now delayed increasing risk to lives.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. 

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Make energy use more sustainable by making unsustainable energy more expensive.
attributes.background: If we change the prices on different types of energy, we could help people make a different choice. Make sustainable energy more mass-produced by making it cheaper, and making unsustainable energy more expensive.
attributes.additional_details: I want the Government to do it because energy pollution is a big problem and this could be a good way to solve it. If the Government do it it could be a big advantage to the country.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you're concerned about sustainability of energy, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.
Decisions about the cost of energy are a matter for generators and Ofgem, not the UK Government or Parliament.

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to increase taxes on generators of non-renewable energy, to make renewable energy comparatively cheaper, if that's something you'd like to happen.

attributes.action: Ban single-use plastic bottles of water
attributes.background: Ban all plastic bottled water. We can easily use tap water and save the environment. If needed, we could add water dispensers in shops so you can fill up your own bottle. Some towns and cities have already banned plastic water bottles so it is not that difficult!
attributes.additional_details: It will help climate change because the factories that make the bottles  will not be producing as much carbon dioxide and it will help plastic pollution a lot because there will not be as many plastic bottles in the seas and in our environment.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552450.

attributes.action: 292 buses to turn their engines off while stationary at rossington ave, bwood
attributes.background: Rossington ave /Wetherby road residents need some help with fumes and noise coming off the busses, leaving  their engines running while stationary. Causing more pollution , this is no good for our environment  and health
attributes.additional_details: TFL who rent the bus route to metroline are doing absolutely nothing about these issues, WE NEED CHANGE AND CLEAN HEALTH

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a matter for TfL and the Mayor of London.

attributes.action: Reduce illegal excessively noisy car and motorbikes to create quieter streets
attributes.background:
Noise pollution makes the lives of people in communities across Britain an absolute misery and has very serious health impacts

New camera technology was to be trialled by government to measure sound levels of passing vehicles to detect those that are breaking the law on noise limits.
attributes.additional_details:
The government needs to crack down on the nuisance drivers who blight our streets.

In 2019 the Department for Transport stated they would target drivers who disturb communities with a crackdown on vehicles which are breaking legal noise limits.
This technology may lead the way in making our towns and cities quieter

Research commissioned by the Department for Transport, found that a noise camera system could help tackle extremely noisy vehicles which breach legal noise limits.

rejection.details:
We understand that you're concerned about cars and motorbikes that exceed legal noise limits, but it's not clear what you want the Government to do about this.

We can only accept petitions that call on the Government to take a specific action.

We have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Reduce the maximum legal noise limit for motorbikes: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/321103

You could start a new petition calling on the Government to take a specific action in respect of this issue, such as providing funding for the deployment of noise cameras, or to provide an update on the trials that were announced last year.

attributes.action: Ban the wholesale of fireworks
attributes.background: To only allow organised displays on or around the 5th of November and New Year.
attributes.additional_details: It is unfair to frighten nervous pets, to farm animals and wildlife to be subjected to the constant explosive sound all year round. It is a form of noise pollution that is unchecked and un policed.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: 

Make fireworks illegal to buy, with the exception of public displays:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/591501

attributes.action: Ban jet aircraft.
attributes.background: The clear blue skies during lockdown, when very few jets flew, as demonstrated to many people just how much pollution  jet aircraft cause.
attributes.additional_details: Ban jet flights to and from the UK, and from overflying UK airspace. Ban jet aircraft (other than military aircraft, or those used for licenced research, or technological development purposes) from taking off or landing ( other than in emergency threatening loss of life) from the UK, and from overflying UK airspace.

attributes.action: Make recycling mandatory and make recycling bins easily available
attributes.background: Have recycling bins around schools and cities to make more people recycle
attributes.additional_details: I want parliment to do this because pollution is a massive issue and i believe that it needs to be stopped

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or House of Commons is responsible for.

Decisions about recycling policies and availability of recycling bins are a matter for individual local authorities, not the Government or House of Commons.

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to make it a legal requirement for people to recycle where possible, and fund increased availability of recycling bins across the country, if that's something you want to happen.

attributes.action: Stop water being Traded on the Stock Market
attributes.background: I would like you to help stop the trade of water as a commodity.
attributes.additional_details:
I don't want water being used as a trading commodity as I believe no-one should control access to water.  Having large corporations controlling access to water will lead to deprivation in certain places, pollution in others and violence as people try to protect their access to their own water supplies from the corporations or groups trying to claim it.
Everyone should have access to free water it is a basic human right.

rejection.details:
The Government is not responsible for what stocks are able to be bought and sold on the stock exchange, or for how companies operate in water market outside of the UK. The London Stock Exchange is regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority.

The UK Government is responsible for setting the rules that apply to the UK's water market, and we have published the following related petitions, which you might like to sign: 

Nationalise water companies: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/548586

Stop water company monopoly - Extend competition to the residential water market: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334537

attributes.action: Keep Stoke-on-Trent's Victoria and Eutria Roads Open!
attributes.background: We request that the Government (DEFRA) gives Stoke-on-Trent City Council a further extension of time to look at alternatives to the proposed closures of Victoria Road A50 and Eutria Road A53, during peak hours, to help bring the city's air quality in line with DEFRA’s Air Quality Directive.
attributes.additional_details:
The closure of these key roads in the City of Stoke-on-Trent will only act to move pollution into residential areas, as traffic takes alternative routes to their destination. It will also have a detrimental effect on residents and businesses that rely on access to their properties on these roads.

The proposed closures are also a temporary measure to meet targets quickly, where as the alternatives proposed, given more time, will offer a permanent solution to reducing air pollution in this city.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise.  Decisions on how to improve air quality in line with the Government's direction are a matter for the council.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:

https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors 

We could publish a petition calling for the Government to extend the deadline, if that's what you'd like to see happen.

attributes.action: Create more “no fish zones” on UK coast to set a precedent for global treaty
attributes.background:
Create and manage more “no fish zones” to allow biodiversity in the oceans to restore itself. 
Set an example for the rest of the world.
attributes.additional_details:
The oceans are vital in removing carbon-based pollutants from the atmosphere and storing them (known as carbon sinks). 
A treaty over international waters in order to restore the health of our oceans is absolutely necessary. No fish zones will allow those species of fish who are over-fished to thrive and bring their population back. This will, in turn, cause an exponential increase in all fish population. 
We will then be able to provide all the food we will ever need from the sea.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign some of these petitions:

Ban fishing on a third of UK coastal for fish repopulation: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/553334

Reform food, energy, environmental and fishing policy to save the planet: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/554376

attributes.action: Tougher laws for home bonfires and chimneys causing  air polution in cities.
attributes.background:
Review the health costs asociated with air pollution in cities.
Review the new sience about the many conditions caused by and worsened by air polution. Conduct local measurements of levels and types of air polution.
New rules to allow hotspots of pollution to ban home bonfires and chimney fires.
attributes.additional_details: Ultimately to provide some way for comunities that are plagued by air polution from open fires, bonfires, stoves, to stop the polution by new rules.

attributes.action: Implement a robust nationwide strategy to reduce littering

Community service in the form of litter picking for those caught littering more than once

Signage in hotspots showing the environmental impact of littering and penalties
attributes.additional_details:
The UK has an increasing problem with of littering. It is believed that 62% of people drop litter.

The cost to the government is approximately £1billion (40,000 nurses or 434,000 school meals)

Litter has a devastating impact on nature, killing millions of animals every year and leads to vast pollution, 

Research has shown that litter leads to tensions within communities and impact on the mental health of residents

The UK need an effective long term plan to solve this problem.

attributes.action: Once repaired close the A57 Glossop to Ladybower each Sunday to motor vehicles.

attributes.additional_details: Government studies show the huge benefits to mental and physical health from an active lifestyle, especially if this takes place in the countryside. Creating a safe space will allow more people to explore by foot, bike, wheelchair or mobility scooter helping people live healthier lives

attributes.action: Compostable packaging must be used all for fresh food and takeaway containers
attributes.background: Manufacturers of all goods that have a short shelf life, such as readymade sandwiches and snacks, must package their goods using only materials that will degrade or compost quickly. These materials, such as starch-based plastic alternatives, are effective, hygienic and readily available.
attributes.additional_details:
Currently, items which can only sit on the shelves for 48hrs are packaged in materials which last for hundreds of years.

Despite decades of anti-litter campaigns, our countryside is still strewn with plastic litter every day, damaging our wildlife and waterways.

This simple change would help reduce the masses of needless non-recyclable waste being generated and reduce plastic litter pollution. With effective alternative materials readily available, now is the time to enforce their use.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition which calls for a very similar action:

'Ban packaging that is not biodegradable or domestically recyclable': https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/574939

You might also like to sign this petition which calls for a relation action: 

'Make it illegal to manufacture or sell products using non-recyclable plastic':
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/561894

attributes.action: Maintain the UK ban on bee-harming pesticides and use of Neonicotinoids
attributes.background: We ask the government to maintain the ban on on all outdoor uses of the neonicotinoid Thiamethoxam. This is proven to be harmful to bees and other wildlife.  We need safeguards to prevent the pollution of run off water containing the chemical at a time when British insects are in serious decline.
attributes.additional_details:
In 2018 Michael Gove, then the environment secretary, said: “The weight of evidence now shows the risks neonicotinoids pose to our environment, particularly to the bees and other pollinators which play such a key part in our £100bn food industry, is greater than previously understood… We cannot afford to put our pollinator populations at risk.”
He also wrote in the Guardian: “Unless the evidence base changes again, the government will keep these restrictions in place after we have left the EU.”

rejection.details:

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids

attributes.action: Block the extension of the ULEZ to cover all of London
attributes.background: Stop the ULEZ from being extended to cover all of London - It has already been extended once with a minimal effect on pollution compared to the vast amount of tax payer money wasted one it. This money could be put to better use than trying to 'catch out' more drivers.
attributes.additional_details:
Despite Sadiq Khan's assurances, the first ULEZ extension has caused massive problems for residents caught inside the zone, and people that work in the zone - Not just commuters but independent tradesmen such as electricians, plumbers, mechanics etc.
On top of this, the price of new and used ULEZ compliant vehicles has increased dramatically, putting them out of the reach of most people who are already struggling with increased bills and day to day costs of living.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the issue you raise is not the responsibility of the Government or Parliament. It is the responsibility of the Mayor of London and the London Assembly.

Revoke local government powers to charge CAZ, LEZ, ZEZ and ULEZ: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/618266

attributes.additional_details: Instead of cutting pollution, because many drivers have to take longer routes, doing increased mileage in heavy traffic, which due to these schemes are all forced onto heavily congested roads using increased fuel consumption and causing an increase in pollution.  These traffic charging schemes and ULEZ zones have been a complete failure and all, including the London charges, should be scrapped without delay.

attributes.action: Renationalise the water industry
attributes.background: Privitisation has failed. The government must take control of the water industry once again and fix the sewerage network which is not fit for purpose, with sewage pollution rampant and an estimated 3,112,700,000 litres of water lost to leaks every day.
attributes.additional_details:
Since the water industry was privatised in 1989 sewage pollution has gradually spiralled out of control, causing enormous environmental harm, damage to tourism and coastal economies and risking public health.

Meanwhile greedy, profiteering water companies are making record profits, led by directors earning millions of pounds per year. This money could be reinvested into upgrading the sewerage infrastructure to a modern standard.

attributes.action: E10 - rebate on road duty/tax
attributes.background: If the government are forcing us to use e10 fuel in petrol cars and it is less polluting, cars that have been forced to use it should get a lower tax rating (vehicle road duty)
attributes.additional_details: We are taxed/charged duty on the pollution our vehicles make, if a cleaner fuel (e10) is being used at nearly all pumps, then we should get a reduction in road tax/duty.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

While E10 fuel is becoming the standard grade in Great Britain this summer, drivers will not be forced to use it and will still be able to use E5 by purchasing the ‘super’ grade (97+ octane) petrol from most filling stations: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/e10-petrol-explained

If you want all vehicle tax rates to be reduced because E10 fuel has been made standard we could accept a petition requesting that, or if you wanted drivers to be able to apply for a rebate based on purchases of E10 fuel, we could also accept a petition requesting that, but it would need to be clear how you wanted this to work.

attributes.action: Investigate and resolve the noise and hygiene issues on the London Underground.
attributes.background: Carry out an audit across the Underground network, measuring the noise pollution between each station and hygiene on each train. Resolve the cause of associated noise and hygiene issues. Then setup a department in the TFL to regularly clean and maintain the network above current standards.
attributes.additional_details: It is the artery of London, which connects both commuter and tourist to their destination. The effects of the dirt and noise pollution on the network are experienced everyday and pose a H&S risk to all that use the network. Passengers are often forced to plug their ears to avoid the extreme volumes of noise, reaching decibels that will probably cause chronic harm when exposed to on a daily basis. Compared to other networks around the world there is much to improve on the service we receive.
